editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE FRENCH ALPHABETH, TEACHING IN A VERY SHORT TIME, BY a moſt eaſie way, to pronounce French naturally, to reade it perfectly, to write it truely, and to ſpeake it accordingly.

p.hi: Together vvith THE TREASVRE OF THE French toung, conteyning the rareſt Sentences, Pouerbes, Parables, Similies, Apothegmes, and Golden ſayings, of the moſt excellent French Authours, as vvell Potes as Orators.

div.p: The one diligently compiled, and the other painfully gathered and ſet in order, after the Alphabeticall maner, for the benefite of thoſe that are deſirous of the French-toung.
By G. D. L. M. N.
AT LONDON Printed by R. Field, and are to be ſold by H. Iackson, dwelling in Fleetſtreet, beneath the conduit, at the ſigne of S. Iohn the Euangelist. 1592.

div.head: A TRES-ILLVSTRE, ET TRES-HEROIQVE LE SIEVR HENRY WALLOPPE Cheualier, & Threſorier General de ſa Sereniſſime Maieſté en Irlande.
div.p:
MONSIEVR, le principal but, ou doibuent viſer toutes nos Actions, eſt d'auoir plus d'eſgard au bien publicq, qu'à noſtre propre vtilité. Et combiē que tous ne ſoyent ſuffiſans de proffiter en choſes grandes, ils ne doibuent neantmoins auoir honte de s'employer es petites. Car comme il n'y a membre, qui, pour quelque excellence qu'il puiſſe auoir, ne paye tribut de ſeruitude au corps, dont il eſt vne partie: auſſin'y a il nul (s'il n'eſt du tout monſtre en nature) qui ne vueille ou doibue procurer, en tout ce qui luy ſera poſſible, l'aduancemēt du Corps dela Republicque, dont luy meſme
eſt vn membre. A ceſte cauſe, encore que le flambeau ardant de la guerre ciuile, qui maintenant conſume noſtre pauure France, ait tellement bruſlé les aiſles de mes Eſtudes, & rompu le col a ma fortune, qu'il m'a du tout deſrobé les moyēs de luy faire quelque bō ſeruice: toutesfois ie n'ay voulu viure du tout inutile, ſinō à ma patrie, au moins a ceux, qui au lieu d'icelle m'ont aymé, embraſſé, & chery. Eſtant doncq refugié a l'ombre fauorable du Sceptre de fa Sereniſſime Maieſté, qui eſt le vray port de retraicte, & Aſyle aſſeuré de ceux, qui faiſans profeſſion de l'Euangile, ſouffrent ores perſecution ſoubs la Tyrannie de l'Antechriſt, i'ay taſché, de tout mon pouuoir, de faire en ſorte par mes labeurs, que ceſte Noble Nation, qui maintenant nous ſert de mere & de nourrice, peuſt tirer quelque proffit d'iceux, afin
que par ce moyē ie peuſſe euiter le vice enorme de l'ingratitude, vice autant deteſtable, que l'hoſpitalité, & largeſſe eſt louable. Or entre toutes les belles, & rares vertus, dont la Nobleſſe Angloiſe ſe rend tant renommée par tout le monde, admirée des Eſtrangiers, & honorée en ſon païs, eſt l'Eſtude des bonnes lettres, & cognoiſſance des langues, qui leur ſont ſi familieres & communes, qu'il s'en trouue peu parmy eux, non ſeulement entre les Seigneurs, & Gentils-hommes, qui n'en parlent trois ou quatre pour le moins, mais auſſi entre les Dames, & Damoiſelles, exercice veritablement louable, par lequel toute
vertu s'honore & ſe rend immortelle, & ſans lequel nulle autre n'eſt parfait, n'y digne d'eſtre aucunement eſtimé. Or c'eſt ce qui, outre la ſinguliere affection, que naturalement ils portent aux eſtrangers, & la grande courtoiſie, dont ils ont accouſtumé de les traicter, leur fait faire tant d'eſtat des François, ſi bien qu'il y en a fort peu, qui n'en ait vn auec ſoy. Ce qui m'a eſmeu, voyant noſtre Nation leur eſtre tant redeuable, de leur faire (pour l'obligatiō de mō particulier) ce petit Traicté, que i'ay intitulé The French Alphabeth, par lequel i'eſpere qu'ils trouuerōt cy apres la langue Françoiſe auſſi aiſée à pronōcer, que cy deuant ils l'eſtimoyēt mal aiſée & difficile. le m'en raporte neantmoins (Monſieur) a ce meur & ſain iugemēt, dont auec la balāce de la raiſon, vous auez accouſtumé de peſer iuſtement de toutes choſes, vous, dy-ie, à qui la langue Françoiſe eſt auſſi naturelle, que la voſtre propre. C'eſt pourquoy ie prēs la hardieſſe de luy faire voir le iour ſoubs voſtre Nom, m'aſſeurant que ſi vous daignez le couurir du manteau de voſtre accouſtumée faueur, & le prēdre en voſtre protectiō, les griffes de l'enuie ne le pourront aucunemēt offencer. Et ce qui m'a eſmeu de le vous dedier pluſtoſt qu'a nul autre, eſt
que , des il y a trois ans paſſez, que i'eu ceſt hōneur d'eſtre cogneu de vous, &
que de voſtre grace il vous pleut me faire tāt de faueur de me dōner accés en voſtre maiſon, par le moyen de Monſieur HENRY WALLOPPE voſtre fils aiſné,
qui ſuyuant les glorieuſes traces de vos heroïques vertus, ſe fait par les belles parties, qui ſont en luy, non ſeulement aymer d'vn chacun, mais auſſi donne eſperance à tous de produire, des ſouaues fleurs du Prin temps de ſa douce ieuneſſe, de beaux, & ſauoureux fruicts de la vertu, à l'honneur, & gloire de Dieu, au ſeruice loyal de ſon Prince, & au bien, & proffit de ſa patrie, ie vey reluyre en vous tant d'eſtincelles de l'Ancienne, & vraye Nobleſſe, & depuis en ay de plus en plus remarqué tāt d'effects,
que i'ay penſé ne luy pouuoir choiſir plus fauorable parrain. Ie vous ſupplie donc affectueuſement de l'auoir pour aggreable, & luy faire auſſi bon accueil,
que treſ-humblement ie le vous preſente, dont ie ne fay aucune doubte, veu qu'entre les vertus, qui vous font reſpecter de tous en general, & honorer d'vn chacun en particulier, la ſinguliere douceur, & manſuetude, qui vous accompagne, & vous rend ſi affectionné aux Eſtrangers, & ſpecialement aux François, m'en aſſeure. Et en ceſt endroit, ie prieray Dieu.

closer.salute: MOnſieur, vous donner en ſanté treſ-heureuſe, & longue vie.
closer.signed: Voſtre treſ-humble, & treſ-affectionné ſeruiteur. G. Delamothe N.

div.head: AN AGRAMME DVDICT SIEVR.

lg.head: QVATRAIN.
lg.l: Quand Lacheſis ourdit le fil de voſtre vie,
Clotho, ſoubs voſtre Nom, chantoit de vous ainſi:
Il ira triumphant du Temps, & de l'Enuie,
Puis que L'HONEVR L'APPVYE, & le maintient auſſi.

lg.head: SONNET ACROSTICHE.
lg.l: Honeur fils des Vertus, & frere de Louange,
Eſt nourry du Nectar, qui s'influe des cieux:
Né de parens diuins, il vit entre les Dieux,
Rendant diuin celuy, qui ſoubs ſon bras ſe range.
Ya-til rien plus grand? Il fait (merueille eſtrange)
Wiure apres le trepas les hommes vertueux;
Woire il les pouſſe encor, d'vn vol audacieux,
Ains leur Soleil couché, d'Albion iuſqu'au Gange.
Lhomme eſt trois fois heureux, qui l'eſlit pour appuy.
Le Temps, qui ſappe tout, n'a de pouuoir ſur luy,
Ores qu'il ſoit touſiours aſſailly de l'Enuie.
Partant HENRY WALLOPPE eſt ſeur cōtre le Temps,
Puis que L'HONEVR L'APPVYE, & bienheurāt ſes ans.
Eterniſe ſon Nom, & decore ſa vie.

div.head: AN EPISTLE TO THE READER, VVARNING HIM OF THE MEthode that he ought to keepe in learning the French-toung.

p.hi: THe firſt and chiefeſt degree of learning (gentle Reader) is a mutuall loue and agreement, betweene him that doth teach, and him that doth learne: I hope that both are both in you and me. In you, becauſe you ſeeke for me, and hauing found me, keepe me in your companie, and delight to talke with me. In me, becauſe I haue with very great payne and care, compiled this booke, onely for you, I spare no tyme to doe you good, and preferre your furtheraunce before myne owne ſtudies. But before we goe any further, it is my duety to teach you faithfully, the methode that you ought to keepe, if you will ſhortly reape the fruite of your hope, and gather the ſweet premiſſes of

my liberall promiſe: you being then ſo deſirous to be taught of me, as I am willing to inſtruct you, I doe not doubt, but you will be ſo carefull to obſerue both my methode and my rules, ſo warie to performe the ſame, and ſo constant to continue in them, as I haue bene painefull and earneſt to inuent them, diligent to preſcribe, and am willing to further you by them. They be fewe, and ſo the more eaſie to learne, and leſſe hard to practiſe: and thus much for our mutuall loue. And as for the other, you meane to learne quickly, and I purpoſe to teach you ſpeedely, and ſo we agree. But as I haue taken great paynes in gathering theſe rules, ſo you muſt ſpare no labour in learning them, and ſo we ſhall agree to. For do not thinke that my booke is able by himſelf to make you a good Frēchmā, except for your part you will play the diligent ſtudient, as for it, it will teach you faithfully. There is nothing though neuer ſo eaſie if one goe vnwillingly about it, and beſides be not well taught, but he ſhall finde it moſt hard. There is nothing though neuer ſo hard, if one go with a deſire to it, an earneſt labour about it, vſe diligēce in it, and be well taught, but is quickly learned, and founde moſt eaſie. Therefore if you will willingly obſerue my rules, and carefully keepe my methode, I doe not doubt, but you ſhall finde the Frēch toung ſo eaſie, as other before haue tried it hard: and ſhall receiue ſuch benefit thereby, that you wil neuer repēt to haue learned of me, nor I to haue taught you. For I hope that ſhortly you ſhall receiue the fruite of your hope, the profite of your labour, and
I thankes for the reward of my payne.

The firſt thing I deſire you to obſerue is, that you will vouchſafe to learne perfectly, and aboue all things both your letters and your ſyllables. Be not loth to ſpend three or foure dayes about them, for thoſe foure dayes will do you more profit, then foure monethes ſpent without the learning of them.

Secondly, whē you haue them perfectly, begin to read, but before, ſpell foure or fiue times euery word, though neuer ſo ſmall, one after another: And for the beginning take but three or foure lines at once, or more or leſſe according as your capacitie can reach, and your paciēce permit. And in your ſpelling & reading, let not paſſe any letter nor ſyllable, without bringing thē to the tryall of your rules, to know if either they muſt be ſounded after the Engliſh faſhion or no, what differēce there be betweene thē, what letter muſt be pronoūced & what not: and why it is pronoūced or not. I haue ſpokē of thē particularly, ſo that if you haue neede of any of thē, you ſhal finde them in their order, and the generall rules after.

Thirdly, whē you can read truely, and pronoūce perfectly, thē go about to Engliſh it, you haue in this booke the Engliſh tranſlation word for word, to teach it you. When you vnderſtand it, and are able to Engliſh it, thē copie out the French, and write it in ſome paper booke, the which you ſhall haue prouided for that purpoſe. Then after hauing ſhut your Frēch Alphabeth, write vnder the French, the Engliſh that you can giue to it: that being done, conferre your tranſlation with your

booke, and amende your faultes if you haue committed any. After that lay away from you the French, and trye if you can put your Engliſh tranſlation into Frēch againe. Continue this order for a moneth euery day, repeating three or foure tymes, both your letters and your ſyllables, & reading and Engliſhing as many times your old, from the beginning, till your later leſſon: leaſt in learning the one, you ſhould forget the other, and beſides that, the old may be a helpe to the new. Being once able to read and pronounce perfectly with your rules two or three leaues of your booke at the moſt, I can aſſure you, that there is not any Frenche booke, though neuer ſo hard, but you ſhall be able to read and pronounce it as truely as can be wiſhed for. For in leſſe then in a leafe of your booke, all your rules are to be obſerued, three or foure tymes at leaſt. For there is no word but in it is one or two rules to be noted. This way will ſeeme to you at the beginning very hard, and ſo though it be more painefull then hard, it is in deede the hardeſt of the French toung, except it be faithfully taught, and alſo diligently learned. But though in it ſelfe it is without teaching, not onely the hardeſt, but alſo, as if it were impoſſible to attaine, you ſhall finde it the moſt eaſieſt, if you will learne, and be ruled by theſe rules.

Fourthly, when you know all the rules of your true pronounciation, and can exactly obſerue them in reading, then go forward ſpeedely in your booke, and euery day tranſlate of it out of French into Engliſh, and out

of Engliſh into French, as much as you can, repeating often your old, leaſt you ſhould forget it. This is the only readieſt way to inſtruct you, not only in the right reading, and naturall pronounciation of the French toung, and in the perfect knowledge and vnderstanding of the ſame, but alſo to make you write it truely, and ſpeake it accordingly. Without chaunging of methode, keepe this order ſtill, not letting paſſe any day without learning ſome thing, and you ſhall finde, in leſſe then fiue or ſixe weekes, your labour and diligence, afforde you ſuch profite and aduauncement, that you will wonder at it, and much greater then I dare promiſe you.

Furthermore when you are pretely furthered in it, get you acquainted, if it be poſſible, with ſome French man, to the end you may practiſe with him, by dayly conference together, in ſpeech and talke, what you haue learned. And if you be in a place, where the Frenchmen haue a Church for themſelues, as they haue in London, get you a French Bible, or a new Testament, and euery day goe both to their Lecture and Sermons. The one will confirme and ſtrength your pronounciation, and the other to vnderſtand when one doth speake.

Finally, if you haue a deſire both to vnderſtand perfectly the hardest and moſt eloquent French, and to ſpeake it naturally, you must prouide you ſome French Dictionarie, and the hardeſt booke you can finde, then tranſlate it, after the maner that I haue preſcribed

you before, or if you will not take the payne to tranſlate (though it be the ſurest and ſhorteſt way) read it diligently and picke out in ſome booke, both the hardeſt wordes, and the beſt phraſes to ſerue your turne, either to ſpeake or to write, when you haue neede of.

div.p: But becauſe without Grammar it is almoſt impoſſible to ſpeake perfectly, but with a very great labour, and long tract of tyme, if this my French-Alphabeth, whom I ſend you for an herbenger of my great loue, and good will I beare you, can finde any fauour at your handes; I will ſhortly ſent you a FRENCH TVTOR, that will teach you in ſo ſhort and eaſie way, as may be both, by the perfect knowledge of the partes of your ſpeeches and Syntaxe, not onely to speake perfectly, but alſo to know if one doth not ſpeake well, to reproue him when he doth ſpeake ill, and to teach him how to amend his bad ſpeeche, a thing which yet before hath neuer bene taught. The promiſe is great, but the performance ſhall not be leſſe, if this be acceptable vnto you. If I ſatisfie you, I doe ſatisfie my ſelfe, deſiring the one, becauſe I wiſhe for the other. But if my wiſhes doe not aunſwere to your expectation, I pray you let your fauorable curteſie waſhe my fault in the ſtreames of the good will I beare you: And in that deuotion. I bid you farewell.

div.head: AN ADVERTISEMENT to the Reader.
div.p: GEntle Readers, if there be any of you, that for your better furtherance in the French toung, ſhall be deſirous to be acquainted with the Authour of this booke, you ſhall heare of him, in Fleetſtreet beneath the conduit, at the ſigne of S. Iohn th'Euangeliſt, where this booke is to be ſold: or els in Paules Churchyard at the ſigne of the Helmet. And there you ſhall finde him very willing to ſhow you any fauour and curteſie he may: and moſt ready to endeuour himſelfe to ſatisfie you, in all that can be poſſible for him to do. And thus. Fare you well.

div.head: Des lettres en general. Of the letters in generall.

list.label: MOnſieur, vous plaiſt il me faire tant de faueur, ou voudriez vous prendre la peine de m'apprēdre a parler Frāçois?

item.hi: SIr, will it pleaſe you to do me ſo much fauour, or would you take the paine to teach me to ſpeake French?

list.label: Treſ-uolontiers, ſi vous en auez enuie.

item.hi: With all my hart, if you haue a deſire to it.

list.label: Ie ne deſire rien plus.

item.hi: I deſire nothing more.

list.label: Si vous le deſirez, vous l'apprendrez biē toſt,

item.hi: If you deſire it, you ſhall learne it quickly,

list.label: S'il vous plaiſt de prendre vn peu de peine.

item.hi: If it pleaſe you to take ſome paine.

list.label: Il ny a rien ſi difficile, qui par labeur ne ſoit facile.

item.hi: There is nothing, though neuer ſo hard, but by labour is made eaſie.

list.label: Vous dites vray. Ie vous en croy.

item.hi: You ſay true, I beleeue you.

list.label: Et pour mon regard, ie ſuis content de prendre quelque peine, pourueu qu'elle ne ſoit en fin perdue; & que i'en puiſſe recepuoir apres & le plaiſir, & profit.

item.hi: And as for me I am contented to take ſome paine, ſo that in the end it be not lost, and that I may receaue afterward, both the pleaſure, and the benefite thereby.

list.label: N'en doutez point, ie vous en aſſeure, ie feray tout ce qu'il me ſera poſſible, pour faire que vous ne ſoyez fruſtré, & de voſtre attente, & du fruit de voz labeurs.

item.hi: Make no doubt thereof, I warrant you, I will do the beſt I can that you may not be fruſtrated, both of your hope, and of the fruits of your labours.

list.label: Ie vous remercie de bien bon coeur.

item.hi: I thanke you with all my hart.

list.label: Vous me ferez vn ſingulier plaiſir.

item.hi: You ſhall do me a great pleaſure.

list.label: Ie n'en ſeray point ingrat.

item.hi: I will not be ingratfull for it.

list.label: Ie le ſçauray bien recognoiſtre.

item.hi: I will endeuour my ſelfe to requite it.

list.label: Ie n'en fay point de doute.

item.hi: I make no doubt thereof.

list.label: Ie m'en remets du tout a voſtre courtoiſie.

item.hi: I will leaue that to your courteſie.

list.label: N'apprintes vous iamais deuant?

item.hi: Did you neuer learne before?

list.label: Nenny, ſi peu que rien, bien,

item.hi: No, ſo litle as nothing, well,

list.label: Tant mieux, i'en ſuis bien aiſe.

item.hi: It is the better, I am very glad of it.

list.label: Il vous ſera plus aiſé d'apprendre, & a moy de vous enſeigner.

item.hi: It will be the more eaſie for you to learne, and for me to teach it you.

list.label: Or ſus, commençons donc?

item.hi: Go to, let vs begin then:

list.label: Quand il vous plaira.

item.hi: When it pleaſe you.

list.label: Commençons par les lettres?

item.hi: Let vs begin with our letters.

list.label: De la prononciation des lettres, ſe forment les ſyllabes, & des ſyllabes ſe font les mots.

item.hi: Of the pronounciation of the letters are made the ſyllables; and of the ſyllables are made the wordes.

list.label: Qui vne fois peut bien prononcer ſes lettres, ne peut qu'il ne prononce bien les mots les plus difficiles.

item.hi: He that once can pronounce well his letters, can not chuſe but to pronounce well, the hardest wordes.

list.label: Et qui veut apprendre a lire, ſans premierement ſçauoir parfaictement prononcer, & les lettres & les ſyllabes, ne lira iamais bien.

item.hi: And he that will learne to read, without knowing first, how perfectly to pronounce, both his letters and ſyllables, ſhall neuer read well.

div.head: Des ſyllabes ſimples. Of the ſingle ſyllables.

list.label: MOnſieur, ſeauez vous voſtre leçon?

item.hi: SIr, can you ſay your leſſon?

list.label: Auez vous apprins a prononcer vos lettres?

item.hi: Haue you learned to pronounce your letters?

list.label: Ouy, le mieux qu'il m'eſt poſſible.

item.hi: Yea, as well as I can.

list.label: Ie n'ay fait autre choſe qu'eſtudier, depuis que vous me feites dire hier.

item.hi: I haue done nothing els but ſtudied it, ſince you did heare me yeſterday.

list.label: C'eſt tresbien fait, i'en ſuis bien aiſe.

item.hi: It is very well done, I am glad then.

list.label: Or-ſus, que ie voye cōment vous prònoncez?

item.hi: Go to, let me heare how you do pronounce?

list.label: Ie le veux, i'en ſuis content.

item.hi: I will, I am content.

list.label: Dites doncq, commencez, parlez haut, prononcez diſtinctement. Tout beau.

item.hi: Say then, begin, ſpeake aloud, pronounce diſtinctly. Softly,

list.label: Ne vous haſtez point, ouurez la bouche.

item.hi: Make no haſt, open your mouth.

list.label: Voyla qui va bien, cela eſt bien dict.

item.hi: That is very well: that is well ſaid.

list.label: Repetez encores vne fois, de rechef.

item.hi: Repeate it once againe. Againe.

list.label: Prononce-ie bien? ouy, vous prononcez biē.

item.hi: Do I pronounce well? Yea, you pronounce well.

list.label: Aydez moy, ie vous prie,

item.hi: Helpe me, I pray you.

list.label: Comment ſe prononce ceſte lettre?

item.hi: How do you pronounce that letter?

list.label: Deuant que paſſer outre il faut que vous prononciez vos lettres parfaictement.

item.hi: Before we go any farther you muſt pronounce perfectly your letters.

list.label: Maintenant que vous ſçauez vos lettres.

item.hi: Now that you can tell your letters well,

list.label: Apprenez vos ſyllabes, dictes apres moy.

item.hi: Learne your ſyllables, ſay after me.

div.head: Des ſyllabes compoſees. Of the double ſyllables.

list.label: BOn iour Monſieur,

item.hi: GOod morrow ſir,

list.label: comment vous portez vous?

item.hi: How do you?

list.label: A voſtre ſeruice, & moy a voſtre commandement.

item.hi: At your ſeruice, and at your commaundement.

list.label: Ie ſuis au voſtre, ce ſera moy qui vous obeiray.

item.hi: I am at yours, I will obey you.

list.label: Vous eſtes bien venu, & bien? ſçauez vous maintenant vos ſyllabes?

item.hi: You are well come, how now? can you pronounce your ſyllables?

list.label: Ouy, que ie penſe, ie ne ſcay.

item.hi: Yea, as I thinke, I can not tell.

list.label: Vous plaiſt il voir? I'en ſuis content,

item.hi: Will it pleaſe you to heare me? I am content.

list.label: Ou eſt voſtre liure? le voyla, le voicy.

item.hi: Where is your booke? there it is, here it is.

list.label: Or dites maintenant, vous triomphez,

item.hi: Say now. You ſay very well:

list.label: Vous prononcez tresbien. Il vous plaiſt de dire ainſi, c'eſt pour me dōner courage.

item.hi: You pronuonce very well. It pleaſeth you to ſay ſo, it is to encourage me.

list.label: Ie ne doubte point, qu'en peu deiours, vous ne pronōciez & liſiez parfaictemēt, pourueu que vous vous reſouueniez bien de la prononciation & de vos lettres, & de voz ſyllabes.

item.hi: I do not doubt, but in few dayes you ſhall pronounce, and read perfectly, ſo that you remember well the pronunciation both of your letters, and of your ſyllables.

list.label: Mais d'autant qu'il y'a d'autres ſyllabes a apprendre, apprenons les parfaictement, deuant que commencer a lire.

item.hi: But becauſe there be ſome other ſyllables to learne, let vs learne them perfectly, before we begin to read.

list.label: Tout ce qu'il vous plaira, ie ſuiuray voſtre aduis.

item.hi: As it pleaſe you, I will follow your counſell.

row.cell: ent 3. perſon of the plurall of verbes.

div.head: De la prononciation. Of the pronunciation.

list.label: MOnſieur, d'ou vient que la prononciatiō de la langue Françoiſe differe tant de la prononciation del Anglois?

item.hi: SIr, what is the cauſe that the pronunciation of the French toung doth differ ſo much from the Engliſh pronunciation?

list.label: Et qu'encor qu'on puiſſe bien lire en Anglois, il ne le peut en François?

item.hi: And that although one can read Engliſh well, yet he can not read French?

list.label: Toute la difference eſt en la prononciation des lettres, eſt-il poſſible? ouy.

item.hi: All the difference is, in the pronunciation of the letters, is it poſſible? yea:

list.label: Car nous prononçons tout autrement nos lettres, que les voſtres.

item.hi: For we do pronounce our letters otherwiſe, then ye yours.

list.label: Car vous ſçauez (comme i'ay dit deuant) que de la prononciation des lettres, ſe fait la prononciation des ſyllabes: & de la prononciation des ſyllabes, ſe fait la prononciation des mots, & de la vraye prononciation des mots, ſe fait la vraye prononciation de la langue Françoiſe, & ainſi des autres: ſi bien qu'il faut touſiours commencer par les lettres, & ne paſſer point outre qu'on ne les ait parfaictement.

item.hi: For you know (as I haue ſaid before) that of the pronunciation of the letters, is made the pronunciation of the ſyllables: and of the pronunciation of the ſyllables, is made the pronunciation of the wordes: and of the true pronunciation of the wordes, is made the true pronunciation of the French toung, and likewiſe of others: ſo that it behoueth alwayes to begin with the letters, and not to go any further, till one hath them perfectly,

list.label:
Comme eſtant le premier degree d'apprēdre, & le ſeur fondement ſur lequel eſt baſty la cognoiſſance de quelque lāgue
que ce ſoit.

item.hi: As they being the firſt degree of learning, and ſure ground wherupon is builded the knowledge of any toung what ſceuer.

list.label: Il me ſera fort difficile d'oublier noſtre prononciation, pour apprendre la voſtre.

item.hi: It will be very hard for me to forget our pronunciation, for to learne yours.

list.label:
Il n'eſt pas de beſoin
que vous oubliez la voſtre,

item.hi: It needes not that you ſhould forget yours,

list.label: mais il eſt neceſſaire que vous vous reſouueniez de la noſtre.

item.hi: but it is neceſſarie that you ſhould remember ours.

list.label: Rome ne fut pas toute baſtie en vn iour.

item.hi: Rome was not builded in one day.

list.label: Cela ſe fera peu a peu, & auec le temps.

item.hi: That will be done by litle and little in time.

list.label: Pouuāt vne fois parfaictement pronōcer vos lettres, & leur donner leſon & l'accent propre, il vous ſera puis apres fort aiſé de lire:

item.hi: Being able once to pronounce perfectly your letters, and to giue the true ſound and fit accent, it will be afterward very eaſie for you to read:

list.label: Pouuant vne fois parfaictement lire, & prononcer, il vous ſera fort aiſé de l'entendre:

item.hi: Being able once to read and pronounce perfectly, it will be very eaſie for you to vnderſtand it.

list.label: Et le pouuāt vne fois parfaictement entendre, il vous ſera fort aiſé de le parler.

item.hi: And being able once to vnderstand it, it will be very eaſie, for you to ſpeake it.

list.label: L'on ne ſçauroit parler, ce que l'on n'entend point: & l'on ne ſçauroit entendre, ce que l'on ne peut ou lire ou prononcer.

item.hi: One can not ſpeake, what he can not vnderſtand: and one can not vnderstand, what he can neither read nor pronounce.

list.label: Vous dites vray: ſans doubte.

item.hi: You ſay true: without doubt.

list.label: Il faut donc commencer par la pronōciation des lettres: car le profit en eſt double.

item.hi: One muſt then begin with the pronunciation of the letters: for the profit is double of it.

list.label: Il vous ſeruira non ſeulement a bien lire, mais auſſi a parfaictement eſcrire.

item.hi: It will auaile you not onely to read truely, but alſo to write perfectly.

list.label: Car les meſmes reigles qui vous monſtrerōt l'vn, vous enſeigneront l'autre.

item.hi: For the ſelfe ſame rules that ſhew you the one, will teach you the other.

list.label: De ſorte que ſi vous gardez ceſt ordre, il n'y a mot ſi difficile qu'en moins de huict ou quinze iours, vous ne prononciez auſſi bien qu'vn François naturel;

item.hi: So that if you will keepe well this order, there is no word, though neuer ſo hard, but in leſſe then in ſeuen night, or a fourthnight, you ſhall pronounce it as well as any French man borne:

list.label: & qu'en trois ſepmaines ou vn mois au plus tard, vous en puiſſiez parfaictement eſcrire.

item.hi: and in three weekes, or within a moneth at the moſt, you ſhall be able to write it truly.

list.label: Eſt il poſſible? vous me faictes eſmerueiller: toutesfois ie vous en croy, car vos raiſons ſont vray ſemblables.

item.hi: Is it poſſible? I wonder at it: notwithſtanding I beleeue you, for your reaſons are likely.

list.label: Et d'autant que deuant que paſſer outre, ie deſire ſçauoir, ſi ie ſçay bien mes lettres, & quelle difference il y a entre voſtre prononciation & la noſtre, ie vous prie de m'enterroguer, & ie vous reſpondray.

item.hi: And before we go any further, I wold faine know, if I can pronoūce my letters, and what difference there is betweene your pronunciation and ours. I pray you aske me, and I will anſwer you.

list.label: Ceſt bien dit, i'en ſuis content.

item.hi: It is well ſaid, I am content.

div.head: De la Diuiſion des lettres. Of the Diuiſion of the letters.

list.label: COmbien y a il de lettres, en la langue Françoiſe?

item.hi: HOw many letters are there in the French toung?

list.label: Il y en a vingt & deux.

item.hi: There are two and twentie.

list.label: Qui ſont elles? A, b, c, d, e, f, &c.
list.item: Which be they? A, b, c, d, e, f, &c.
list.label: En combien de parties ſont elles diuiſees?

item.hi: Into how many parts are they diuided?

list.label: En deux parties.

item.hi: Into two parts.

list.label: Qui ſont elles?

item.hi: Which be they?

list.label: Voyelles, & Conſonantes.

item.hi: Vowels and conſonants.

list.label: Qu'eſt-ce qu'vne voyelle?

item.hi: What is a vowell?

list.label: Vne voyelle eſt vne lettre, qui de ſoy meſme a voix, & ſe prononce d'elle meſme cōme a.
list.item: A vowell is a letter, which of it ſelfe hath a voyce, & is pronounced with it ſelf, as a.
list.label: Combien y a il de voyelles?

item.hi: How many vowels are there?

list.label: Six, aſçauoir A, e, i, o, u, y.
list.item: Six, to wit, a, e, i, o, u, y.
list.label: Qu'eſt-ce qu'vne conſonante?

item.hi: What is a conſonant?

list.label: Vne Conſonante eſt vne lettre, qui n'a nul, ſon ou voix, ſans l'vne des voyelles, cōme b, c, d, &c. qu'on ne ſçauroit pronōcer ſans la voyelle é.
list.item: A conſonant is a letter which hath neither ſound nor voice without one of the vowels, as, b c d, &c. the which cannot be pronounced without the vowell é.
list.label: Combien y a il de Conſonantes?

item.hi: How many conſonants are there?

list.label: Quinze: ceſt aſçauoir b c d e f g l m n p q r ſ t x z.
list.item: Fifteene: that is to ſay, b c d f g l m n p q r ſ t x z.
list.label: Pourquoy laiſſez vous h?
list.item: Wherefore do you leaue out h?
list.label: Par-ce que h, n'eſt ny voyelle ny conſonante.

item.hi: Becauſe it is neither a vowell nor a conſonant.

list.label: Qu'eſtce-donc?

item.hi: What is it then?

list.label: H, eſt vne aſpiration, par laquelle le mot ou elle ſe trouue ſe prononce auec plus de vehemence qu'on ne feroit autrement, comme hanter, & non pas anter.
list.item: It is an aſpiration, by the which the word wherein it is, is pronounced with greater vehemence then it would be otherwiſe, as, hanter, and not anter.
list.label: En combien de parties, ſont diuiſees les Conſonantes?

item.hi: Into how many parts are the conſonants diuided?

list.label: En deux parties, aſçauoir, Muettes & Liquides.

item.hi: Into two, to wit, Mutes and Liquides.

list.label: Qu'eſt-ce qu'vne Muette?

item.hi: What is a Mute?

list.label: Vne Muette eſt vne conſonante, qui deuant vne autre conſonante, excepté deuant l, ou r, n'eſt iamais pronouncée, ſoit au commencement, ſoit au milieu, ſoit a la fin, ou d'vn mot, ou d'vne ſyllabe, comme vous me faictes grand tort certes:
list.item: A Mute is a conſonant, which before an other conſonant, except before l and r is neuer pronounced, either in the beginning or in the midst, or the end, either of a word or of a ſyllable, as vous me faictes grand tort certes.
list.label: Liſez, vou me faite gran tor certes.
list.item: Reade, Vou me faite gran tor certes.
list.label: Donnez moy vne exemple ou deux, ou les muettes ſont prononcees deuant l, & r? craindre, plaindre, front, fleute, grand, &c.
list.item: Giue me an example or two, wherein the Mutes are pronounced before l and r. craindre, plaindre, front, fleute, grand, &c.
list.label: Et encore cela s'entend quand l, & r, ſont dans la meſme ſyllabe que la conſonante, car autremēt elles ne ſont point pronōcees, comme grand lieu, haut roc.
list.item: And yet that is to be vnderſtood when l and r be in the ſelſe ſame ſyllable, for if it be otherwiſe, they be not pronounced, as grand lieu, haut roc.
list.label: Il faut lire gran lieu, hou roc.
list.item: It muſt be read, gran lieu, hou roc.
list.label: 'P, & x, ſont auſſi prononcez au milieu d'vn mot, mais non pas a la fin, comme exces, excepter, exprimer, &c.
list.item: P and r be alſo pronounced in the midſt of a word, but not in the end, as exces, excepter, exprimer. &c.
list.label: N'y a il point d'autre exception des muettes?

item.hi: Is there none other exception of the Mutes?

list.label: Si a, car ſ, encore qu'elle ſoit muette eſt touſiours prononcee aux mots qui ſont deriuez des Latins comme eſtimer, eſprit, teſtifier, &c.
list.item: Yes: for though ſ be a mute, yet it is alwayes pronounced in the words which are taken out of the Latin toung, as eſtimer, eſprit, teſtifier, &c.
list.label: Il faut excepter Chreſtien, honneſte, teſmoing, Creſpin, beſte, reſte, preſter, & tout le verbe estre, &c.
list.item: You muſt except, Chreſtien, honneſte, teſmoing, Creſpin, beſte, reſte, preſter, and all the verbe eſtre &c.
list.label: Ceſte exception n'a lieu qu'aux mots Latins ſeulement, car aux vrays mots François s, n'eſt iamais prononcee, deuant vne autre conſonante, comme bruſler, meſme, eſlire, touſiours, meſchant, eſchapper, &c. Il les faut prononcer bruler, méme, élire, touiours, méchant, échapper.
list.item: This exception hath no power but in the Latin wordes onely, for in the true French words ſ is neuer pronounced before an other conſonant, as bruſler, meſme, eſlire, touſiours, meſchant, eſchapper, &c. They muſt be pronounced bruler, méme, touiours, méchant, échapper.
list.label: Combien y a il de muettes?

item.hi: How many mutes are there?

list.label: Vnze, aſçauoir b c d f g p q s t x z.
list.item: Eleuen, to wit, b c d f g p q ſ t x z.
list.label: Qu'eſt-ce qu'vne liquide?

item.hi: What is a Liquide?

list.label: Vne liquide eſt vne conſonante, qui eſt touſiours prononceé, ſoit au commencement, ſoit au millieu, ſoit a la fin d'vn mot, ou d'vne ſyllabe, comme vn mal ſur mal; bon renom.
list.item: A Liquide is a conſonante which is alwayes pronounced either in the beginning or the midſt, or in the end of a word, or of a ſyllable, as vn mal, ſur mal; bon renom.
list.label: Il faut excepter l, deuant s, t, x, a la fin ou d'vne ſyllabe, ou d'vn mot, comme hault, faulx, fils, prononcez haut, faus, fis, &c.
list.item: You must except I, before s, t, or x, at the end either of a ſyllable or of a word, as hault, faulx, fils, &c. pronounce haut, faux, fis, &c.
list.label: Combien y a il de liquides?

item.hi: How many liquides be there?

list.label: Quatre, aſçauoir l, m, n, r.
list.item: Foure, to wit l m n r.
list.label: N'y a il point de voyelles, qui puiſſent eſtre conſonantes?

item.hi: Is there not any vowell, that can be a conſonant?

list.label: S'y a. Quelles?

item.hi: Yes. Which be they?

list.label: I, & v, quand ils ont quelque autre voyelle apres eux, eſtant au commencement ou d'vn mot, ou d'vne ſyllabe, comme ie, Ieſus, i'ay, touſiours, vous, auoir, ſçauoir, & v, ayant r, apres luy, comme viure, vray, &c.
list.item: I, and v, when there foloweth another vowell being in the beginning either of a word, or of a ſillable, as ie, Ieſus, i'ay, touſiours, vous, auoir, ſçauoir, & v, hauing r, folowing, as viure, vray, &c.
list.label: Car s'ils ſont ou au milieu, ou a la fin d'vne ſyllabe ils ne ſont pas conſonantes, comme cogneuë, folie, &c.
list.item: For if they be either in the midſt, or at the end of a ſyllable, they be not conſonants, as cogneue, folie; &c.
list.label: Quelle difference y a il entre i, & y?
list.item: What difference is there betweene i, & y?
list.label: Nulle quant a la prononciation,

item.hi: None concerning their pronunciation,

list.label: mais grande quant a l'orthographe.

item.hi: but very great concerning their writing.

list.label: Quelle, ie vous prie?

item.hi: What difference I pray you?

list.label: I, eſt touſiours mis au commencement d'vn mot ou d'vne ſyllable, comme iamais, touſiours, & lors eſt conſonante: ou au millieu d'vne ſyllabe ayant e, ou vne conſonante apres luy, comme mis, mais fait, lieu, & lors eſt voyelle:
list.item: I, is alwayes in the beginning of a word or of a ſyllable as iamais, touſiours, and then is a conſonant: or in the midſt of a ſyllable hauing e, or a conſonant folowing, as mis, mais fait, lieu and then it is a vowell:
list.label: y eſt touſiours ou a par ſoy, comme y a il, ou au millieu d'vn mot, ayant vne voyelle apres pour le diſtinguer de i, conſonant, comme ayant, voyant, yeux, & non aiant, voiant, ieux, ou a la fin d'vn mot comme i'ay, i'iray, i'auray.
list.item: y is alwayes either by it ſelfe, as y a il, or in the midſt of a word hauing a vowell following for to know it from i, conſonant, as ayant, voyant, yeux, and not aiant, voiant, ieux, or it is in the end of a word, as i'ay, i'iray, i'auray.
list.label: Il faut excepter ces mots qui, ſi, vei, fei. &c.
list.item: We muſt except theſe wordes qui, ſi, vei, fei, &c.

div.head: Des voyelles. Of the vowels.

list.head: a
list.label: COmment prononcez vous la lettre a?
list.item: HOw do you pronounce the letter a?
list.label: A ſe prononce ouuert & long, comme ce mot Anglois awe, to be in awe, comme ma, ta, ſa, la, bat, part, blanc. &c.
list.item: A, is pronounced plaine and long, as this Engliſh word awe, to be in awe, as ma, ta, ſa, la, bat, part, blanc, &c.

list.head: ai
list.label: Commēt prononcez vous la diphthōgue ai?
list.item: How do you pronounce the diphthong a?
list.label: ai ſe prononce cōme ce mot Anglois haie, ayant oſté h; ou comme e, neutre, ou comme la diphthongue Angloiſe ea,
list.item: ai, is pronounced like this Engliſh word haie, hauing taken away h, or els like e, neutre, or els like the Engliſh diphthong ea,
list.label: comme paix, mais, iamais, faire.
list.item: as paix, mais, iamais, faire.
list.label: Il faut prononcer commes'il eſtoit eſcript, peace, mes, iameas, feare, &c.
list.item: We muſt pronounce as if it were written, peace, mes, iameas, feare, or fere.

list.head: ain
list.label: Comment ſe prononce ain?
list.item: How do you pronounce ain?
list.label: ain ſe prononce ein, comme ainſy, pain, main, prononcez einſy, pein, mein, &c.
list.item: ain is pronounced like ein, as ainſy, pain, main, pronounce einſy, pein, mein, &c.

list.head: au
list.label: Comment ſe prononce au?
list.item: How do you pronounce au?
list.label: Au ſe prononce comme o long, ou ce mot Anglois owe, comme auſſi, Paul, d'autant, aucun, prononcez óſſi, pól, dót ant, ocun.
list.item: au is pronounced like an O long, or elſe like this Engliſh word owe, as auſſy, Paul, d'autant, aucun, pronounce, óſſy, Pól, d'ótant, ócun.

list.head: ay
list.label: Comment ſe prononce ay?
list.item: How do you pronounce ay?
list.label: Ay ſe prononce comme é maſculin long: comme i'ay, feray, i'iray, prononcez i' é feré i'iré, Exceptez fay, may, geay, cathay, fontenay, partenay, l'aunay, ou il ſe prononce, comme e neutre.
list.item: ay will be pronounced like é maſculine long, as i'ay, feray, i'iray, reade, ié, feré, i'iré, Except fay, may, geay, cathay, fontenay, partenay, l'aunay, wherein ay is ſounded like e neuter.

list.head: e
list.label: Comment prononcez vous e?
list.item: How do you pronounce e?
list.label: Diuerſement: pourquoy?

item.hi: Diuerſly: why?

list.label: Pour-ce qu'il y en a de trois ſortes.
list.item: Becauſe there be three kinds of e.
list.label: Qui ſont ils?

item.hi: Which be they?

list.label: é maſculin, e feminin, & e neutre.
list.item: é maſculine, e feminine, e neuter.

list.head: é maſculin.
list.label: Comment cognoiſſez vous é maſculin?
list.item: How ſhall one know é maſculin?
list.label: é maſculin eſt noté d'vn accent ſur la teſte comme é.
list.item: é maſculin is noted with an accent ouer his head as this é.
list.label: Comment ſe prononce é maſculin?
list.item: How do you pronounce e maſculin?
list.label: Il ſe prononce comme e de la fin de ce mot Latin amare: ou comme e du mot Anglois the, comme paré, pré, bonté, beauté, &c.
list.item: It is pronoūced like the e at the end of the Latin word amare: or like e of this Engliſh word the, comme paré, pré, bonté, beauté, &c.

list.head: e feminin.
list.label: Comment ſe cognoiſt e feminin?
list.item: How is e feminin to be knowen?
list.label: e feminin eſt cogneu quand il n'a aucun accent ſur la teſte, comme e.
list.item: e feminin it knowen when it hath not any accent ouer his head, as this e.
list.label: Comment ſe prononce e feminin?
list.item: How is e feminin pronounced?
list.label: e feminin ſe prononce au commencement auec difficulté, par les eſtrangers de la langue Françoiſe, d'autant qu'il eſt peculier au François ſeulement, ſi bien qu'il en faut apprendre la prononciation d'eux; il ſe prononce preſque comme e de ces mots Anglois able, table, poſſible; amiable, toute la difference eſt que les Anglois le prononcent comme s il eſtoit deuant l; & l'eſtouffent en la bouche, en preſſant leur palais auec leur langue, ou au contraire les François luy donnent ſa prononciation apres l, en ouurant vn peu la bouche
list.item: It is very hard for the ſtrangers of the French toung, in their beginning, to pronounce e feminin, becauſe it is peculiar to the Frenchmen onely, ſo that the pronunciation thereof can not be learned, but in hearing them to ſound it. it is almoſt ſounded like e of theſe Engliſh wordes, able, table, poſſible, amiable, all the difference is that the Engliſhmen do pronounce it as if it were before l, and they ſmoother it in their mouth, preſſing the palet with their toung, where contrariwiſe the Frenchmen do giue him his ſound after l, opening a litle their mouth
list.label: pour luy donner ſortie, comme donne, faute, porte, race, vn chacun de ces mots eſtant de deux ſyllabes.
list.item: to giue him iſſue out, as donne, faute, porte, race, ech one of theſe words being of two ſyllables.

list.head: e neutre.
list.label: Comment ſe cognoiſt e neutre?
list.item: How is e neuter to be knowne?
list.label: e neutre n'eſt point noté, non plus que e feminin, mais il eſt touſiours deuant ou l, ou r, ou s. Cela s'entend quand il eſt en la meſme ſyllabe qu'eſt ou l, ou r, ou s, comme belle, terre, eſtre, &c.
list.item: e neuter is not noted, no more then e feminin, but it is alwayes before either l or r, or ſ. That is to be vnderſtood when e is in the ſelfe ſame ſyllable that either l, or r, or ſ, be, as belle, terre, eſtre, &c.
list.label: Exceptez le plurier des noms qui ſe finiſſent au ſingulier par e feminin, comme choſes, toutes, belles, &c. auſquels e demeure touſiours feminin, excepté les mots d'vne ſyllabe, comme des, les, ſes, tes, es, auſquels e eſt neutre.
list.item: Except the plurall number of the nownes which do end their ſinguler nūber with e feminine, as choſes, toutes, belles, &c. in the which e remaineth alwayes feminine, except the words of one ſyllable, as des, les, mes, ſes, tes, es, in the which e is neuter.
list.label: Comment ſe prononce e neutre?
list.item: How do you pronounce e neuter?
list.label: e neutre ſe prononce ouuert & long, comme ces mots Anglois haie, ou may, en oſtant h de haie, & m de may, ou bien comme la diphthongue ea, en ce mot peace, comme elle, ferme, preſt, &c. prononcez ealle, fearme, preaſt.
list.item: e neuter is ſounded both plaine and long, as theſe Engliſh words, hay, may, taking away h from haie, and m from may, or elſe like the diphthong ea of this word peace, as elle, ferme, preſte, &c. pronounce ealle, fearme, preaſt.
list.label: N'y a il point de mots ou les trois e ſe trouuent?
list.item: Is there not any word wherein your three e can be found?
list.label: Si a, comme honnesteté, dont le premier
list.item: Yes, as this word honneſteté, whereof the firſt.
list.label: e eſt neutre, a cauſe qu'il eſt deuant s, & ſe prononce long: le ſecond feminin, a cauſe qu'il n'eſt point noté d'vn accent, & ſe prononce brief: & le dernier maſculin, noté, & ſe prononce comme e ou Anglois ou Latin.
list.item: e is neuter, becauſe it is before ſ, & it is pronounced long: the ſecōd e is feminin, becauſe he hath no accent ouer his head, and is pronounced ſhort: and the laſt is maſculin, noted with an accent, & is ſounded like Engliſh e.
list.label: Comment ſe prononce e deuant m, ou n?
list.item: How do you pronounce e before m or n?
list.label: e deuant m, ou n, ſe prononce comme vn a, pourueu que e ſoit en la meſme ſyllabe que m, ou n, comme femme, entre, prendre, il l es faut prononcer comme s'ils eſtoyent eſcripts famme, antre, prandre.
list.item: e before m or n is pronounced like an a, ſo that e be in the ſelfe ſame ſyllable that m or n are, as femme, entre, prendre, pronounce them as if they were written famme, antre, prandre.
list.label: Ceſte reigle n'a elle point d'exception?

item.hi: Hath not this rule any exception?

list.label: Si a, il faut excepter, quand i va deuant e, car lors e eſt prononcé comme e, & non pas comme a, comme bien, mien, tien, ſien, &c.
list.item: Yes, we muſt except when i is before e, for then e is pronounced like e, and not like a, as bien, mien, tien, ſien, rien, vien.
list.label: Cela s'entend quand i & e ſont en la meſme ſyllabe que n, car s'il n'eſt en la meſme ſyllabe, e ſe prononce ſelon la reigle generale, c'eſt aſçauoir comme a, comme ſapience, audience, conſcience, &c. dans leſquels mots, ou leurs ſemblables e eſt prononcé comme a, encore qu'il ait i deuant, a cauſe que i n'eſt pas en la meſme ſyllabe que e. If fault done prononcer ſapiance, audiance, conſciance, &c.
list.item: That is to be vnderſtood when both i & e be in the ſame ſyllable that n is in: for if it be not in the ſame ſyllable, e is ſounded according to the generall rule, to wit like an a, as ſapience, audience, conſcience, &c. in which words, or their like e is ſounded like a, though that i be before e, becauſe i is not in the ſame ſyllable wherein is e. pronounce then ſapiance, audiance, conſciance, &c.
list.label: La reigle generale de e deuant n n'a elle point d'autre exception?
list.item: Hath not the generall rule of e before n any other exception?
list.label: Si a. Qu'elle?

item.hi: Yes. What is it?

list.label: C'eſt que e deuant n de la troifieſme perſonne du plurier des verbes ne ſe prononce iamais comme a, mais comme e.
list.item: It is that e before n in the third perſon of the plurall of verbes is neuer pronounced like a, but like e
list.label: Pourquoy?

item.hi: Why?

list.label: La raiſon eſt, que n n'eſt iamais prononcée a la troiſieſme perſonne du plurier des verbes, & dont e eſt feminin, comme firent, ſautent, danſent, auoyent, il faut prononcer firet, ſautet, danſet, auoyet.
list.item: Becauſe n is neuer pronounced in the third perſon of the plurall of verbs, in the which e muſt be ſoūded feminin, as firent, ſautent, danſent, auoyent, pronounce firet, ſautet. danſet, auoyet.

list.head: ei.
list.label: Comment ſe prononce la diphthongue ei?
list.item: How do you pronounce the diphthong ei?
list.label: ei ſe prononce comme e maſculin, comme ſeigner, ſeize, peigner, &c. prononcez ſégner, ſéze, pégner, &c.
list.item: ei is pronounced like é maſculine, as ſeigner, ſeize, peigner, &c. ſound ſégner, ſeze, pegner, &c.
list.label: Ceſte reigle n'a elle point d'exception?

item.hi: Hath not this rule any exception?

list.label: Si a. Combien? Deux.

item.hi: Yes. How manie? Two.

list.label: Qu'elle eſt la premiere?

item.hi: Which is the first?

list.label: La premiere eſt de ces deux mots vei, & fei, & de leurs deriuez, comme veit, feit, veirent, feirent, ou i eſt prononcé, & non pas e. Il faut donc lire vi, fi, virent, firent, &c.
list.item: The firſt is of theſe words vei, and fei, & of thoſe that are deriued of thē, as veit, feit veirent, feirent, wherein i is pronounced, and not e. Reade then vi, fi, virent, firent, &c.
list.label: Quelle eſt la ſeconde?

item.hi: Which is the ſecond?

list.label: La ſecond eſt quand n ſuit apres ei, car lors é & i ſont tous deux prononcez, comme peindre, creindre, veine, ceindre.
list.item: The ſecond is when n followeth ei, for then both e and i are pronounced, as peindre, creindre, veine, ceindre.

list.head: eu.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous eu?
list.item: How do you pronounce eu?
list.label: eu ſont prononcez u, comme feu, peu, vouleu, Dieu, lieu, prononcez fu, pu, voulu, Diu, liu, retenant neantmoins vn peu de la prononciation de e.
list.item: eu is pronounced like u onely, as feu, peu, vouleu, Dieu, lieu, pronounce fu, pu, voulu, Diu, liu, keeping notwithſtanding ſomewhat the pronunciation of e.

list.head: i.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous i?
list.item: How do you pronounce i?
list.label: iſe prononce comme le double ee Anglois, comme fit, mit, rit, pris, ſuit, liſez feet, meet, reet, prees, ſueet.
list.item: i is pronounced like the double Engliſh ee, as fit, mit, rit, pris, ſuit, reade feet, meet, reet, prees, ſucet.

list.head: ë, ï,
list.label: Comment prononcez vous ë, & î, notez de deux points ſur la teſte, en ce maniere ë i? ë, & i, notez en ceſte maniere ſont diuiſez de la voyelle precedente, & font vne ſyllabe apart, comme pais, veuë, creu-ë, na-if, ba-ïf: po-ëte. liſez pa-ïs, veu-ë, creu-ë, na-if, ba-ïf: po-ëte.
list.item: How do you pronounce ë and ï noted with two points ouer their head in this manner ë, ï? ë and ï noted after this maner are diuided from the vowell going afore, and they make a ſyllable by them ſelues, as païs, veuë, creuë, naïf, baïf, poëte, Reade pa-is, veu-é, creu-ë, na-ïf, ba-ïf, po-ëte.

list.head: o.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous o?
list.item: How do you pronounce o?
list.label: o ſe prononce comme ce mot Anglois owe, comme ſot, pot, mot, lot, oſer, oſter. Exceptez fol, ſol, qui ſont fou, ſou.
list.item: o is pronounced like this Engliſh word owe, as ſot, pot, mot, lot, oſer, oſter. Except fol, ſol, which are pronounced fou, ſou.

list.head: oi, oy.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous oi ou oy?
list.item: How do you pronounce oi, or oy?
list.label: oi ou oy ſe prononce comme oé, comme moy, toy, ſoy, toit, boit, roy, loy, Liſez moé, toé, ſoé, toét, hoét, roé, loé, & notez que ceſt e ſe prononce comme é neutre, ou comme la diphthongue Angloiſe ea.
list.item: oi, or oy are pronounced like oe, as moy, toy, ſoy, toit, boit, roy, loy, Reade moé, toé, ſoé, toét, boét, roé, loé, note that this e is pronounced like e neuter, or like the Engliſh diphthong ea.

list.head: oeu
list.label: Comment prononcez vous oeu?
list.item: How do you pronounce oeu?
list.label: oeu ſe prononce u, comme oeuure, coeur, Liſez uvre, cur, en ouurant u, & le faiſant long, comme participant vn peu de e, qui eſt deuant luy.
list.item: oeu are pronounced like u, as oeuure, coeur, Reade uvre, cur, in opening u, and making it long, as borowing ſomewhat of the pronunciation of e, which is before it.

list.head: om
list.label: Comment prononcez vous om?
list.item: How do you pronounce om?
list.label: om ſe prononce comme s'il eſtoit eſcript oun, comme nom, renom, liſez noun, renoum.
list.item: om is pronounced as if it were written oun, as nom, renom, reade noun, renoun.

list.head: on
list.label: Comment prononcez vous on?
list.item: How do you pronounce on?
list.label: on ſe prononce comme s'il eſtoit eſcript oun, comme mon, non, ton, liſez moun, noun, toun.
list.item: on is pronounced as if it were written oun, as mon, non, ton, reade moun, noun, toun.

list.head: ou
list.label: Comment prononcez vous ou?
list.item: How do you pronounce ou?
list.label: ou ſe prononce comme le double oo Anglois, comme nous, vous, tous, ſous. liſez noos, voos, toos, ſoos.
list.item: ou is pronounced like the double Engliſh oo. as nous, vous, tous, ſous, Reade noos, voos, toos, ſoos.

list.head: u
list.label: Comment prononcez vous u?
list.item: How do you pronounce u?
list.label: u ſe prononce comme les Eſcoſſois prononcent u de ce mot Gud, ou u de ce mot lute, comme but, fut, vſer, &c.
list.item: u is pronounced as the Scots do pronounce u of that word Gud, or like the u of that word lute, as but, fut, vſer, &c.

list.head: y
list.label: Comment prononcez vous y?
list.item: How do you pronounce y?
list.label: y ſe prononce tout ainſy que i François, comme le double ee Anglois, comme luy, auſsy, ainſy, ceſtuy, auiourd'huy.
list.item: y is pronounced euen as the French i, or the Engliſh double ee, as luy, auſſy, ainſy, ceſtuy, au iourd'huy.
list.label: liſez lui, oſsi, einſi, ceſtui, oioura'ui.
list.item: Reade lui, oſſi, einſi, cétui, oiourd'ui.

div.head: Des Conſonantes. Of the Conſonants.

list.label: MOnſieur, puis que la prononciation de la langue Françoiſe, & generalement de toutes les autres langues, conſiſte en la prononciation des lettres, mais principalement en celle des voyelles, (d'autant que ſans icelles les conſonātes ne peuuent dōner aucun ſon) & que ce ſont les voyelles, qui donnent voix, & aux ſyllabes, & aux mots; & que nous auons aſſez ſuffiſamment parlé deſdictes voyelles; cela ne ſuffit il pas pour la pronōciation de la langue Frāçoiſe, tant a bien lire, qu'a bien parler?

item.hi: SIr, ſith that the pronunciation of the French tongue, and generally of all the other languages, conſiſteth in the pronunciation of the letters, but eſpecially of the vowels (becauſe that without them the conſonants cannot giue any ſound) and that there be vowels which giue voyce both to the ſyllables and to the words; and beſides that, we haue ſufficiently enough ſpoken of the ſame vowels; will not that ſuffiſe for the pronunciation of the French tongue, as well to reade well, as to ſpeake well?

list.label: Nenny. Car comme la prononciation de nos voyelles differe de la prononciation des voſtres, auſsy la prononciation de nos Conſonantes eſt beaucoup differente de la voſtre, qui fait que voſtre langue, & la noſtre different tant en prononciation.

item.hi: No forſoth. For euen as the pronunciation of our vowelles differeth from the pronunciation of yours; ſo the pronunciation of our Conſonantes is much different from yours, the which thing cauſeth your toung and ours to differ ſo much in the pronunciation.

list.label: Il eſt donc de beſoing que vous ſçachiez, comment nos conſonantes ſe prononcent, & que vous puiſſiez diſcerner la difference qu'il y a entre la prononciation de nos conſonantes, & les voſtres.

item.hi: Then it is needefull for you to know, how our conſonantes are pronounced, and diſcerne the true difference which is betweene the pronunciation of our conſonantes and yours.

list.label: I'ay apprins cela des le commencement, par les tables que vous en auez faictes en ce liure.

item.hi: I haue learned that euen from the beginning, by the tables that you haue made of them in this booke.

list.label: Tant mieux vaut. I'en ſuis bien aiſe.

item.hi: It is the better. I am very glad of it:

list.label: Mais ie deſire ſçauoir ſi vous ne les auez point oubliez. Car il les faut repeter tous les iours, & ſi ſouuent que vous les imprimiez en ſorte en voſtre memoire, qu'elles vous ſoyent auſſi aiſées & familieres, que les voſtres propres. Car ſans cela il eſt du tout impoſſible que iamais vous prononciez bien, ſoit en liſant, ſoit en parlant, ny que vous puiſſiez onc vrayement eſcrire.

item.hi: But I deſire to know if you haue not forgotten them. For you muſt repete them euery day, and ſo often that you may imprint them in ſuch ſort into your memorie, that they be as eaſie and familiar vnto you, as your owne. For without them, it is impoſſible that euer you can pronounce well, either reading or ſpeaking, nor that euer you ſhould write truely.

list.label: Ie vous prie donc de m'interroguer,

item.hi: I pray you then, aske me them,

list.label: pour voir ſi ie les ay point oubliées.

item.hi: to ſee if I haue not forgotten them.

list.label: Ie le veux, & afin de ne vous ennuyer par vn trop long diſcours, i'omettray a cauſe de briefueté, beaucoup de choſes qui ſe pourroyent dire des conſonantes en general, & ne vous interrogueray point particulierement de chaſcune, car ce ſeroit vne choſe ſuperflue. Seulement ie vous examineray; de ce en quoy elles ſont differentes des conſonantes Angloiſes.

item.hi: I will, leaſt I ſhould wearie you by a to long treatiſe, I will omit, for breuitie ſake, many things that might be generally ſpoken of the conſonantes. And I will not aske you particularly of euery one, for it ſhould be a ſuperfluous thing. I will onely examine you vpon that they do differ in from the Engliſh conſonantes.

list.label: Ie vous remercie affectueuſement vous me ferez vn ſingulier plaiſir.

item.hi: I thanke you hartily, you ſhall do me a great pleaſure.

list.label: Or-ſus commençons donc?

item.hi: Go to. Then let vs begin.

list.head: b
list.label: Cōment prononcez vous b a la fin d'vn mot?
list.item: How do you pronounce b in the end of a word?
list.label: b a la fin d'vn mot ne ſe prononce iamais, ſoit qu'il ſuyue vne voyelle, ſoit qu'il ſuyue vne autre conſonante, comme plomb, coulomb, &c. Liſez plom, coulom.
list.item: b being at the end of a word is neuer pronounced, if either a vowell, or another conſonant follow or no, as plomb, coulomb, &c. Read plom, coulom.

list.head: c
list.label: Comment prononcez vous c deuant a, o, & u?
list.item: How do you pronounce c either before a, or o, or u?
list.label: c deuant a, o, & u, ſe pronounce comme k, comme car, cor, curé: liſez kar, kor, kure.
list.item: c before a, o, and u, is pronounced like Engliſh k, as car, cor, curé. Read kar, kor, kuré.

list.head: ç
list.label: Comment prononcez vous ç deuant a ou o, ayant vn crochet deſſoubs marqué
list.item: How do you pronounce ç before a, or o, hauing a marke vnder it noted
list.label: en ceſte maniere ç?
list.item: after this manner ç?
list.label: ç deuant a, ou o, marqué en ceſte maniere, ſe prononce comme vne ſſ, comme viença, maçon, leçon, façon.
list.item: ç before a, or o, noted after this manner, is pronounced like two ſſ, as viença, maçon, leçon, façon:
list.label: Liſez vienſſa, maſſon, leſſon, faſſon.
list.item: Read vianſſa, maſſon, leſſon, faſſon.

list.head: ce, ci
list.label: Comment prononcez vous c deuant e, ou i?
list.item: How do you pronounce c before e, or i?
list.label: c deuant e, & i ſe prononce comme s, comme celuy, cela, cité, ciron.
list.item: c before e, or i is pronounced like ſ, as celuy, cela, cité, ciron:
list.label: Liſez ſeluy, cela, ſité, ſiron.
list.item: Read ſeluy, céla, ſité, ſiron.

list.head: ch
list.label: Comment prononcez vous c deuant h?
list.item: How do you pronounce c before h?
list.label: c deuant h ſe prononce comme s deuant h en Anglois, comme choſe, charge, chef, cheual.
list.item: c before h is pronounced like s before h in Engliſh, as choſe, charge, chef, cheual:
list.label: Liſez ſhoſe, ſharge, ſhef, ſheual.
list.item: Read ſhoſe, ſharge, ſhef, ſheual.
list.label: Il faut excepter Christ, Chriſtophle, Chreſtien, cholere, choleric, ou h n'eſt point prononcée du tout.
list.item: We muſt except Chriſt, Chriſtophle, Chreſtien, cholere, choleric, &c. Wherein h is not pronounced at all.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous c en ces mots ſecond, ſecondement, ſecret, ſecretaire, ſecretement, becaſſe?
list.item: How do you pronounce c in theſe wordes ſecond, ſecondement, ſecret, ſecretaire, ſecretement, becaſſe?
list.label: c ſe prononce en ces mots comme g, il faut doncq prononcer, ſegond, ſegondement, ſegret, ſegretaire, ſegretement, begaſſe.
list.item: c is pronounced in theſe wordes like g, Pronounce then ſegond, ſegondement, ſegret, ſegretaire, ſegretement, begaſſe.

list.head: d
list.label: Comment prononcez vous d
list.item: How doe you pronounce d
list.label: a la fin d'vn mot?

item.hi: at the end of a word?

list.label: d a la fin d'vn mot ſe prononce comme vn t, comme grand, prend, rend, rond.
list.item: d being at the end of a word is pronounced like t, as grand, prend rend, rond:
list.label: Liſez grant, prent, rent, ront.
list.item: Read grant, prent, rent, ront.
list.label: Exceptez bled, pied, ou d n'eſt point prononcé.
list.item: Except bled, pied, in the which d is neuer pronounced.

list.head: g
list.label: Cōment prononcez vous g deuant a, o, & u?
list.item: How doe you pronounce g before a, o, or u?
list.label: g deuant a, o, & u, ſe prononce comme le g Anglois en ces mots Gabriel, God, comme gaber, garde, gobelet, guerdon.
list.item: g before a, o, or u is pronounced like the Engliſh g in theſe wordes Gabriel, God, as gaber, garde, gobelet; guerdon.

list.head: ge gi
list.label: Comment prononcez vous g deuant e, & i?
list.item: How doe you pronounce g before e, or i?
list.label: g deuant e, & i ſe prononce comme i conſonant, non du tout ſi fort que i conſonant Anglois, comme geler, gemir, general, giron, gibbier.
list.item: g before e, or i is pronounced like i conſonant, not altogether ſo hard as i Engliſh conſonant, as geler, gemir, general, giron, gibbier.

list.head: gua.
list.label: Comment prononcez gua?
list.item: How doe you pronounce gua?
list.label: gua ſe prononce comme ga, comme guarir, language, liſez guerir, language.
list.item: gua is pronounced like ga, as guarir, language, Read garir; langage.

list.head: gue.
list.label: Comment prononce vous gue?
list.item: How doe you pronounce gue?
list.label: gue ſe prononce comme ge de ces deux mots Anglois get, geſſe, comme guerdon, langue.
list.item: gue is pronounced like ge of theſe two Engliſh wordes get, geſſe, as guerdon, langue.

list.head: gn.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous g deuant n?
list.item: How do you pronounce g before n?
list.label: gn ſe prononce difficilement par les Anglois, toutesfois s'ils veulent prendre garde, comme ils prononcent minion, onion, companion, il leur ſera plus aiſé de le prononcer, car encore que nous eſcriuions ces meſmes mots par gn neantmoins il y a peu de difference de leur prononciation a la noſtre, ſeulement qu'ils prenent garde a mettre g en la meſme ſyllabe que n, & ils ne trouueront aucune difficulté en ſa prononciation, comme mignon, oignon, compagnon, lignage, ligne, compagnie. Liſez mi-gnon, oi-gnon, compa-gnon, li-gnage, li-gne, compa-gnie.
list.item: gn is hardly pronounced by the Engliſhmen, notwithſtanding if they will take heede how they do pronounce minion, onion, companion, it will be eaſie for them to pronounce it, for though we do write the ſelfe ſame wordes with gn, neuertheleſſe there is ſmall difference betwene their pronunciation and ours, let them take heede onely to ſound g in the ſame ſyllable that n is, and then they ſhall not finde any hardneſſe in his pronunciation, as mignon, oignon, compagnon, lignage, ligne, compagnie, Read mi-gnon, oi-gnon, compa-gnon, li-gnage, li-gne, compa-gnie.
list.label: Exceptez ſigne, cygne, digne, cognoiſtre, & ſes compoſez, ou g n'eſt point pronōcé.
list.item: Except, ſigne, cygne, digne, cognoiſtre, &c Wherein g is not pronounced at all.

list.head: h.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous h?
list.item: How doe you pronounce h?
list.label: h ſe prononce par aſpiration, aſçauoir aux mots qui ſont vrays François, auſquels elle eſt touſiours prononcée, comme hache, hanter, haye, honte, &c. Il faut excepter haleine, huict, helas, heur, heureux,
list.item: h is pronounced with aspiration, to wit in wordes that are true French, in the which h is alwayes pronounced, as hache, hanter, haye, honte, &c. We muſt except haleine, huict, helas, heur, heureux,
list.label: & tous les mots deriuez du Latin, qui ſe commencent par h; comme homme, honneur, heritage, &c. auſquels elle n'eſt iamais prononcée:
list.item: and all the wordes that are deriued from the Latin which begin with h; as homme, honneur, heritage, &c. wherein h is neuer pronounced:
list.label: Liſez donc omme, onneur, eritage, &c.
list.item: Read then omme, onneur, eritage, &c.

list.head: ll
list.label: Comment prononcez vous deux ll au millieu d'vn mot, ayant i deuant, & vne ſimple l a la fin d'vn mot, ayant deux ou trois voyelles deuant?
list.item: How do you pronounce two ll in the midſt of a word, hauing i before: and a ſingle l at the end of a word, hauing two or three vowels afore?
list.label: Deux ll au millieu d'vn mot, ayant i deuant; comme fille, baille: & vne ſimple l a la fin d'vn mot, ayant deux ou trois voyelles deuant, comme oeil, dueil, or gueil, ſe prononcent difficilement par les Anglois, toutesfois s'ils prenent garde comme ils prononcent ces deux mots ſcalion, ſcoulion, il leur ſera plus facile de les prononcer, car elles ſe prononcent preſque de meſme: comme baille, taille, vaille, fille, veille. Excepté ville.
list.item: Two ll in the midst of a word hauing i before, as fille, baille: and a ſingle l at the end of ae word, hauing two, or three vowels before, as oeil, dueil, orgueil, are hardly pronounced by the Engliſhmen, notwithſtāding if they will take heede, how they pronounce theſe two wordes ſcalion, ſculion, they ſhall finde more eaſie to pronounce it: for they are pronounced almost like, as baille, taille, vaille, fille, veille, Except ville.
list.label: Ceſte reigle la n'a elle pas lieu au mots ou il y a vne antre voyelle, que i comme a, e, o, u, deuant deux ll?
list.item: Is not this rule to be vnderstood in the wordes, wherein there is an other vowell then i, as a, e, o, u, before two ll?
list.label: Nenny car lors il n'y a que l'vne des l qui ſe prononce, comme palle, malle, belle, ſelle, folle, nulle, ſeulle: liſez
list.item: No, for then there is but ae ſingle l pronounced as palle, malle, belle, ſelle, folle, nulle, ſeulle, Read
list.label: pale, male, bele, ſele, fole, nulle; ſeulle.
list.item: pale, male, bele, ſele, fole, nule, ſeule.

list.head: m.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous m a la fin d'vn mot?
list.item: How doe you pronounce m at the end of a word?
list.label: in a la fin d'vn ſe prononce comme n, comme nom, renom: liſez non; renon.
list.item: m in the end of a word is pronounced like n as nom, renom: Read non renon.

list.head: ph.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous ph?
list.item: How doe you pronounce ph?
list.label: ph ſe prononce comme f, comme philoſophe, prophete, phlegme:
list.item: ph is pronounced like f, as philoſophe, prophete, phlegme:
list.label: Liſez filoſofe, profete, flegme.
list.item: Read filoſofe, profete, flegme.

list.head: qu.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous qu?
list.item: How doe you pronounce qu?
list.label: qu ſe prononce comme k Anglois, comme qui, que, quiconque, quand:
list.item: qu is pronounced like Engliſh k, as qui, que, quiconque, quand:
list.label: Liſez ki, ke, kiconke, kand.
list.item: Read ki, ke, kiconke, kand.

list.head: r.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous vn ſimple r, au milieu d'vn mot?
list.item: How doe you pronounce a ſingle r being in the midſt of a word?
list.label: r ſimple ſe prononce comme r de ce mot Anglois borow, il la faut prononcer fort doucement, & ſans force, cōme ſi elle eſtoit ioincte auec la lettre de deuant, encore qu'elle ne le ſoit, comme pare, pere, mere, mare, more, guerre, &c.
list.item: a ſingle r is pronounced like r of this Engliſh, word borow, it muſt be pronounced very ſweetly, and without force, as if it were ioyned with the letter going afore, though it be not in deede, as pare, pere, mere, mare, more, guerre, &c.
list.label: Et au commencement d'vn mot elle ſe prononce comme r do ce mot Anglois rauiſh, comme rauir, neprendre.
list.item: And in the beginning of a word r is pronounced like r of this Engliſh word rauiſh, as rauir, reprendre,
list.label: rimer, rome, rumeur.
list.item: rimer, rome, rumeur.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous deux rr?
list.item: How do you pronounce two rr together?
list.label: Deux rr ſe prononcent plus rudement, & auec plus de force que la ſimple r, & ſe prononce comme les deux rr de ce mot Anglois warrier, domme terre, guerre, barre, &c.
list.item: Two rr are pronounced more hardly, and with more force then the ſingle r is; and are pronounced like the two rr of this Engliſh word warrier, as terre, guerre, barre, &c.

list.head: s.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous s entre deux voyelles?
list.item: How doe you pronounce s betweene two vowelles?
list.label: s entre deux voyelles ſe prononce comme vn z, comme choſe, mauuaiſe, priſer:
list.item: s betweene two vowels is pronounced like z as choſe, mauuaiſe, priſer:
list.label: Liſez choze, mauuaize, priſer.
list.item: Read choze, mauuaize, prizer.

list.head: ſſ.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous deux ſſ?
list.item: How doe you pronounce two ſſ?
list.label: Deux ſſ ſe prononcent comme vn c, comme preſſe, feiſſe, foſſe, trouſſe:
list.item: Two ſſ are pronounced like c, as preſſe, feiſſe, foſſe, trouſſe:
list.label: Liſez préce, feice, foce, trouce.
list.item: Read préce, feice, foce, trouce.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous s a la fin d'vn mot?

item.hi: How doe you pronounce s at the end of a word?

list.label: s a la fin d'vn mot ſe prononce comme z, comme pas, bas, nous, vous, tous, rois:
list.item: s at the end of a word, is pronounced like z as pas, bas, nous, vous, tous, rois,
list.label: Liſez paz, baz, nouz, vouz, touz, roiz.
list.item: Read paz, baz, nouz, vouz, touz, roiz.

list.head: th.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous th?
list.item: How doe you pronounce th?
list.label: th ſe prononce comme t ſans h, comme Timothee, theſme, atheiſte:
list.item: th is pronounced like t without h; as Timothee, theſme, atheiſte:
list.label: Liſez Timotee, teſme, ateiſte.
list.item: Read Timotee, teſme, ateiſte.

list.head: tion.
list.label: Comment prononcez vous tion?
list.item: How doe you pronounce tion?
list.label: tion ſe pronōce comme s'il eſtoit eſcript cion, comme action, affection, prononciation:
list.item: tion is pronounced as if it were written cion, as action, affection, prononciation:
list.label: Liſez accion, affection, prononciation.
list.item: Read accion, affeccion, prononciation.

list.head: x.
list.label: Cōment prononcez vous x a la fin d'vn mot?
list.item: How do you pronounce x at the end of a word?
list.label: x a la fin d'vn mot ſe prononce comme z, comme aux, paix, faix, lieux, mieux:
list.item: x at the end of a word is pronounced like z, as aux, paix, faix, lieux, mieux:
list.label: Liſez auz, paiz, faiz, lieuz.
list.item: Read auz, paiz, faiz lieuz, mieuz.

div.head: Des Reigles generales. Of the generall Rules.

list.label:
MAintenant
que nous auōs particulieremēt parlé des lettres Frāçoiſes, tāt voyelles que conſonantes; & que ie ſçay quelle difference il y a entre leur prononciation, & celles des lettres Angloiſes,
que me reſte il pour parfaictement lire & bien parler?

item.hi: NOw ſir, that we haue particularly spoken of the French letters, as well vowels as conſonantes, and that I know what difference there is betweene their pronunciatiō and the Engliſh letters, what lacke I to perfectly read, and ſpeke well?

list.label: Il voꝰ reſte encore quelques reigles generales, qu'il faut diligemment obſeruer, ſans iamais errer a l'encontre, ſi vous deſirez bien prononcer; mais qui ſont fort aiſées, d'autant qu'elles ſont peu en nōbre.

item.hi: You lacke yet ſome generall rules, the which ought diligently to be obſerued, without tranſgreſſing them in any wiſe, if you deſire to prononce well, but they be very eaſie becauſe, they be few.

div.head: La premiere Reigle. The firſt Rule.

list.label: QVelle eſt la premiere?

item.hi: VVHich is the firſt?

list.label: La premiere eſt, que ſi vn mot ſe finiſt

item.hi: The firſt is, that if a word endeth

list.label: par e feminin, & que le mot ſuyuant ſe commence par vne voyelle, e feminin n'eſt iamais prononcé, & les deux, ou trois, ou quatre mots ſont ioincts enſemble, comme s'ils n'eſtoyent qu'vn, comme belle amye ayme eſtre aymée:
list.item: with e femimn, and that the word following beginneth with a vowell, e feminin is neuer pronounced, and the two, or three, or foure wordes are ioyned together, as if they were but one word, as belle amye ayme eſtre aymée:
list.label: Liſez bell-amy-aym-estr-aymée.
list.item: Read bell-amy-aym-eſtr-aymée.
list.label:
Et ſi vn mot ſe finiſt par é maſculin, ou par quelque autre voyelle, &
que le mot ſuyuant ſe cōmence par vne autre voyelle, é maſculin, ou quelque autre voyelle quelle quelle ſoit (excep té e feminin) doibt elle eſtre prononcée?
list.item: But if a word endeth with é maſculin, or with an other vowell, and that the word following beginneth with another vowell, muſt é maſculin, or ſome other vowell whatſoeuer (except e feminin) be pronounced?
list.label: Ouy, dictes donc I'ay donné a mon pere, & non pas i ay donn a mon pere.
list.item: Yea, ſay then I'ay donné a mon pere, and not i'ay donn-a mon pere.
list.label: Prononcez il donna a amour, & non pas il donn amour.
list.item: Pronounce il donna a Amour, and not il donn-Amour.
list.label: Prononcez il eſt vni & ioinct, & non pas il eſt vn & ioinct.
list.item: Sound il eſt vni & ioinct, and not il eſt vn & ioinct.
list.label: Dictes il a coureu a Londres, & non pas il a cour a Londres: & ainſy des autres leurs ſemblables.
list.item: Say il a coureu a Londres, and not il a cour a Londres: and euen ſo of other their like.

div.head: La ſeconde Reigle. The ſecond Rule.

list.label: QVelle eſt la ſeconde Reigle generale?

item.hi: VVHich is the ſecond rule?

list.label: La ſeconde eſt, que ſi vn mot ſe finiſt par vne conſonante, & que le mot

item.hi: The ſecond rule is. If a word endeth with a conſonante, and the word

list.label: ſuyuant ſe commence par vne voyelle, les deux, ou trois, ou quatre mots ſont prononcez enſemble, comme s'ilz n'eſtoyent qu'vn mot, comme il aymoit aſſez a chanter en Muſique, prononcez comme ſice n'eſtoit qu'vn mot, ilaymoitaſſezachanteren Muſique.
list.item: following beginneth with a vowell the two or three, or foure wordes are pronounced together, as if they were but one word, as il aymoit aſſez a chanter en Muſique, pronounce as if it were but one word, Ilaymoitaſſezachanteren Muſique.
list.label: Ceſte reigle n'a elle point d'exception?

item.hi: Hath this rule no exception?

list.label: Nenny, ſinon en ce mot et, qui touſiours eſt prononcé é, ſoit qu'il ait vne voyelle, ſoit qu'il ait vne conſonante apres.
list.item: No, but in this word et, which alwayes is pronounced é, without t, whether a vowell, or a conſonant doth folow after him.

div.head: La troiſieſme Reigle. The third rule.

list.label: QVelle eſt la troiſieſme Reigle generale?

item.hi: VVHich is the third generall rule?

list.label: La troiſieſme reigle eſt, que ſi vn mot ſe finiſt par vne, ou deux conſonantes, & le mot ſuyuant ſe commence par vne autre conſonante, les conſonantes de la fin du mot ne ſont iamais prononcées, comme i'ay faict cela: c'eſt trop toſt parlé:
list.item: The third rule is, if a word endeth with one, or two conſonantes, and that the word following, beginneth with another conſonant, the conſonantes in the end of the word are neuer pronounced, as i'ay faict cela: c'eſt trop toſt parlé:
list.label: Liſez i'ay fai cela. Cé tro to parlé.
list.item: Read i'ay fai cela, cé tro to parlé.
list.label: Ceſtre reiglen'a elle point d'exception?

item.hi: Hath this rule no exception?

list.label: Se a; Il faut excepter les Liquides l, m, n, r, & des Muttes c, quand il eſt le dernier du mot, car s'il eſtoit penultime il ne ſeroit prononcé, comme pour les Liquides mon loyal ſeruiteur faict ſon deuoir. Ila acquis vn nom fameux,
list.item: Yes. The liquides l, m, n, r, are excepted and the muts c, when it is the laſt letter of a word, for otherwiſe it muſt not be pronounced, as for the liquides mon loyal ſeruiteur faict ſon deuoir. Il a acquis vn nom fameux.
list.label: Et pour c, auec moy, vn ſac plain de bled.
list.item: And for c, auec moy, vn ſac plain de bled.

div.head: Apoſtrophe.

list.label: QVe ſignifie ceſte marque' miſe entre deux lettres d'vn mot?

item.hi: VVHat doth this marke 'meane being put betweene two letters of a word?
